titleStmt.title: Von Ludwig Wittgenstein an George Edward Moore, 18. 2. 1914
titleStmt.author: Wittgenstein, Ludwig

sourceDesc.p: Original bei Timothy Moore; Kopie im BA. Publiziert (Letters, S. 147; deutsch: Briefe, S. 51; Cambridge Letters, S. 76f.; WiC, S. 69).

list.item: 2007/06: Conversion from Folio Flat File to XML

div.p: Thanks so much for your letter. I'm sorry I caused you horrid troubles. I didn't really expect such a long account of the meeting. But all you wrote to me interested me enormously because I think I know exactly what Johnson was at. It ‒ of course ‒ all turns on the question as to the nature of deduction. And ‒ I think ‒ the clue to it all lies in the fact that only then expresses the deductive relation when this prop is the generalization of a tautology.

You must come as soon as Term ends and I shall meet you in Bergen. I am looking forward to your coming more than I can say! I am bothered to death with Logik & other things. But I hope I shan't dy before you come for in that case we couldn't discuss much.

P.S. Boats run from Newcastle to Bergen 3 times a week. I shall expect you in Bergen about the 20th of March. What has happened with young Sedgwick whome Hardy [tried] to run? Has he become a member of the Society?
